articles.title: How Weston handled pressure to win Olympic gold and GB's first medal
articles.summary: Matt Weston cements his status as the best skeleton racer in the world, making history by winning Olympic gold in emphatic fashion in Cortina and securing Team GB’s first medal of the 2026 Winter Games.
articles.content:
Standing at the top of the winding Cortina sliding track with Olympic gold in his sights, Matt Weston knew what he had to do.

Having laid the foundations for skeleton gold on Thursday - tidying up errors from his first run to produce a statement second, each time setting the track record - the Briton merely needed more of the same on Friday.

What he produced was not only a masterclass in sliding but also a remarkable display of composure and focus to clinch gold - Team GB's first medal of the Games - and cement his place at the top of the sport.

"It means everything. It means a hell of a lot to me personally, I've worked so hard for this," Weston told BBC Sport.

"But everyone back home - my fiancee, my family, my friends, everyone who has sacrificed everything for this. I've missed funerals, birthdays, everything for this moment. It feels amazing. Hopefully I made you proud."

Weston set a track record on all four of his runs and could have eased off in his final attempt having already built a significant margin of 0.39 seconds, but ramped things up on what was ultimately a victory lap lasting 55.61secs, finishing with a sensational overall time of 3:43.33.

It left an almost impossible task for the chasing pack and Germany's Axel Jungk finished 0.88secs behind to take silver, while compatriot and defending Olympic champion Christopher Grotheer secured bronze, 1.07secs behind Weston.

The pressure to deliver was there. The 28-year-old from Redhill was the heavy favourite to top the podium in Italy having dominated the sport in the past four-year cycle, but no British man had won an Olympic skeleton gold medal before.

He also carried the weight of Team GB teetering on the edge of overall disappointment at the Games, having been tipped for a record medal haul at Milan-Cortina but watching those ambitions begin to slip away.

Weston blocked out the noise of 'helmet-gate', of seeing his peer Vladyslav Heraskevych disqualified from the competition just moments before the first heat, and of the disaster that was Beijing 2022, where GB failed to win a skeleton medal for the first time since 2002.

He put it all aside to add the Olympic crown to his two World Championship titles and three Crystal Globes - the overall World Cup trophies.

Four years ago, it was a different story.

His overwhelming disappointment at missing out on the Olympic podium almost led to him quitting the sport and he told BBC Sport earlier this year he has had to teach himself to "love the pressure and expectation".

From speaking to friends and family to knowing when to rest and eating lots of pasta, Weston has figured out the secret to his own success, and now he's reaping the rewards.

This accomplishment has broad public interest and emotional uplift, showcasing perseverance, dedication, and national pride. articles.personality_title: Matt Weston wins historic Olympic gold in skeleton for Team GB
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Skeleton is a winter sliding sport where athletes race down an icy track on a small sled, headfirst. Britain has never won Olympic gold in men's skeleton before, though the sport is popular and competitive.

**What happened** – Matt Weston, a 28-year-old British skeleton racer, won the Olympic gold medal at the 2026 Winter Games in Cortina, Italy. He set a new track record in all four of his runs, finishing with a total time of 3 minutes and 43.33 seconds. Weston’s win delivered Team GB’s first medal of these Games.

**Impact** – This gold medal is historic because no British man had ever won Olympic skeleton gold before. Weston’s victory also brought hope to Team GB, which had been struggling to win medals at these Games. His win shows how hard work, focus, and learning to handle pressure can lead to success, especially after his disappointment in the last Olympics where he missed the podium.

**What’s next step** – Weston will likely continue competing at the highest level, defending his world titles and possibly aiming for more Olympic success. His achievement might inspire younger athletes in Britain to take up skeleton or other winter sports.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Matt Weston made history by winning Britain’s first Olympic gold in men’s skeleton, showing how determination and calm under pressure lead to success.

articles.title: Roman mosaic in Britain reveals a 2,000 year old Trojan War secret
articles.summary: A remarkable Roman mosaic found in Rutland turns out to tell a forgotten version of the Trojan War. Rather than Homer’s famous epic, it reflects a lost Greek tragedy by Aeschylus, featuring vivid scenes of Achilles and Hector. Its artistic patterns echo designs from across the ancient Mediterranean, some dating back 800 years before the mosaic was made. The discovery suggests Roman Britain was deeply plugged into the wider classical world.
articles.content:
Researchers studying what has been called one of the most important mosaics ever found in the UK say it portrays a rarely told version of the Trojan War that had largely faded from history.

A new investigation by the University of Leicester explains why the well known Ketton mosaic in Rutland -- considered one of the most remarkable Roman era discoveries in Britain in the past century -- does not illustrate scenes from Homer's Iliad, as scholars first believed. Instead, the artwork reflects a different telling of the Trojan War that was made famous by the Greek playwright Aeschylus. That dramatic version has not survived in full and is considered lost.

The findings also show that the mosaic incorporates decorative motifs that had been circulating around the Mediterranean for centuries. This suggests that artists working in Roman Britain were closely connected to broader artistic traditions across the classical world.

Discovery During Lockdown

The Ketton mosaic came to light in 2020 during the COVID-19 lockdown, when local resident Jim Irvine spotted it on his family farm. The discovery led to a major excavation by University of Leicester Archaeological Services (ULAS), funded by Historic England. The mosaic and the surrounding Roman villa have since been granted Scheduled Monument status because of their national significance. Historic England and ULAS carried out joint excavations in 2021 and 2022 and are now preparing the full publication of their findings.

The mosaic features three dramatic moments involving the Greek warrior Achilles and the Trojan prince Hector: their fierce duel, Achilles dragging Hector's body, and the later scene in which King Priam ransoms his son's body, which is shown being weighed in gold.

The Trojan War, most famously described in Homer's epic poem the Iliad, tells of a legendary ten year conflict between Greek forces and the city of Troy, ruled by King Priam. According to myth, the war began after Helen of Sparta was taken to Troy.

Aeschylus and a Forgotten Greek Tragedy

Detailed analysis now indicates that the Ketton mosaic does not follow Homer's narrative. Instead, it closely matches Phrygians, a lesser known tragedy written by the Athenian playwright Aeschylus. While Romans were familiar with multiple versions of the Trojan War story, choosing this more unusual interpretation would have set the villa's owner apart and signaled cultural sophistication.

The study also highlights how the mosaic blends long established artistic designs from across the Mediterranean.

Dr. Jane Masséglia, lead author of the study and Associate Professor in Ancient History at the University of Leicester, said: "In the Ketton Mosaic, not only have we got scenes telling the Aeschylus version of the story, but the top panel is actually based on a design used on a Greek pot that dates from the time of Aeschylus, 800 years before the mosaic was laid. Once I'd noticed the use of standard patterns in one panel, I found other parts of the mosaic were based on designs that we can see in much older silverware, coins and pottery, from Greece, Turkey, and Gaul.

"Romano-British craftspeople weren't isolated from the rest of the ancient world, but were part of this wider network of trades passing their pattern catalogues down the generations. At Ketton, we've got Roman British craftsmanship but a Mediterranean heritage of design."

Roman Britain and the Wider Ancient World

Jim Irvine, who first uncovered the mosaic in 2020, said: "Jane's detailed research into the Rutland mosaic imagery reveals a level of cultural integration across the Roman world that we're only just beginning to appreciate. It's a fascinating and important development that suggests Roman Britain may have been far more cosmopolitan than we often imagine. The new paper is a suspenseful and thrilling narrative in its own right which deserves recognition."

Rachel Cubitt, Post-Excavation Coordinator at Historic England, added: "Working in collaboration with the University of Leicester brings an added dimension to investigations at the Ketton villa site. This fascinating new research offers a more nuanced picture of the interests and influences of those who may have lived there, and of people living across Roman Britain at this time."

Hella Eckhardt, Professor of Roman Archaeology at the University of Reading, who was not involved in the study, said: "This is an exciting piece of research, untangling the ways in which the stories of the Greek heroes Achilles and Hector were transmitted not just through texts but through a repertoire of images created by artists working in all sorts of materials, from pottery and silverware to paintings and mosaics."
articles.reasoning: The discovery of the Ketton mosaic reveals a lost version of the Trojan War narrative and demonstrates deep cultural and artistic connections between Roman Britain and the wider ancient Mediterranean world. This finding enriches historical knowledge and highlights the cosmopolitan nature of Roman Britain, offering significant cultural and educational value with broad public interest.
articles.personality_title: Ancient Roman mosaic in Britain reveals lost Trojan War story
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – A Roman mosaic discovered in Rutland, England, shows scenes from the Trojan War, a famous story from ancient Greece. For a long time, people thought it illustrated the well-known version by Homer, but new research shows it tells a different, forgotten version by the playwright Aeschylus.

**What happened** – In 2020, Jim Irvine found the Ketton mosaic on his family farm during the COVID-19 lockdown. Experts from the University of Leicester studied it and found it does not follow Homer’s story but a rare Greek tragedy called Phrygians by Aeschylus. The mosaic shows three key moments involving the warriors Achilles and Hector, including their fight, Hector’s body being dragged, and King Priam paying gold to get his son’s body back. The mosaic also uses artistic patterns from across the ancient Mediterranean, some dating back 800 years before it was made.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it reveals a lost version of the Trojan War story and shows that people living in Roman Britain were connected to a wide cultural world. The mosaic’s designs link Britain to Greece, Turkey, and Gaul, proving that Roman Britain was not isolated but part of a larger network of art and trade. It also suggests that the villa’s owner was someone with a deep knowledge of classical culture.

**What's next step** – Archaeologists are now preparing to publish their full findings. The mosaic and the villa have been protected as a Scheduled Monument. Researchers hope this will encourage more studies about how Roman Britain connected with other ancient cultures and inspire public interest in history.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A Roman mosaic in Britain reveals a lost Greek version of the Trojan War and shows how ancient Britain was linked to the wider Mediterranean world.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une mosaïque romaine en Grande-Bretagne révèle une version oubliée de la guerre de Troie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Une mosaïque romaine découverte à Rutland, en Angleterre, montre des scènes de la guerre de Troie, une histoire célèbre de la Grèce antique. Pendant longtemps, on a pensé qu’elle représentait la version connue d’Homère, mais de nouvelles recherches montrent qu’elle raconte une version différente et oubliée par le dramaturge Eschyle.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2020, Jim Irvine a découvert la mosaïque de Ketton sur la ferme familiale pendant le confinement lié au COVID-19. Des experts de l’Université de Leicester l’ont étudiée et ont découvert qu’elle ne suit pas l’histoire d’Homère mais une tragédie grecque rare appelée Phrygiens, écrite par Eschyle. La mosaïque montre trois moments clés avec les guerriers Achille et Hector : leur combat, le corps d’Hector traîné, et le roi Priam payant de l’or pour récupérer le corps de son fils. Elle utilise aussi des motifs artistiques venus de toute la Méditerranée antique, certains datant de 800 ans avant sa création.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle révèle une version perdue de la guerre de Troie et montre que les habitants de la Grande-Bretagne romaine étaient connectés à un grand monde culturel. Les motifs de la mosaïque relient la Grande-Bretagne à la Grèce, la Turquie et la Gaule, prouvant que la Grande-Bretagne romaine n’était pas isolée mais faisait partie d’un réseau plus large d’art et de commerce. Cela suggère aussi que le propriétaire de la villa avait une grande connaissance de la culture classique.

**Étape suivante** – Les archéologues préparent maintenant la publication complète de leurs découvertes. La mosaïque et la villa sont protégées en tant que monument classé. Les chercheurs espèrent que cela encouragera d’autres études sur les liens entre la Grande-Bretagne romaine et les autres cultures antiques, et suscitera l’intérêt du public pour l’histoire.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une mosaïque romaine en Grande-Bretagne révèle une version grecque oubliée de la guerre de Troie et montre comment l’ancienne Grande-Bretagne était liée au monde méditerranéen.
articles.personality_title_es: Un mosaico romano en Gran Bretaña revela una versión perdida de la guerra de Troya
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Un mosaico romano descubierto en Rutland, Inglaterra, muestra escenas de la guerra de Troya, una historia famosa de la antigua Grecia. Durante mucho tiempo se pensó que ilustraba la versión conocida de Homero, pero una nueva investigación muestra que cuenta una versión diferente y olvidada del dramaturgo Esquilo.

**Qué pasó** – En 2020, Jim Irvine encontró el mosaico de Ketton en la granja de su familia durante el confinamiento por COVID-19. Expertos de la Universidad de Leicester lo estudiaron y descubrieron que no sigue la historia de Homero sino una tragedia griega poco conocida llamada Frigios, escrita por Esquilo. El mosaico muestra tres momentos importantes con los guerreros Aquiles y Héctor: su pelea, el cuerpo de Héctor siendo arrastrado, y el rey Príamo pagando oro para recuperar el cuerpo de su hijo. También usa patrones artísticos de todo el Mediterráneo antiguo, algunos con 800 años de antigüedad antes de que se hiciera el mosaico.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque revela una versión perdida de la guerra de Troya y muestra que las personas en la Gran Bretaña romana estaban conectadas con un mundo cultural más amplio. Los diseños del mosaico conectan Gran Bretaña con Grecia, Turquía y la Galia, demostrando que la Gran Bretaña romana no estaba aislada sino que formaba parte de una red más grande de arte y comercio. También sugiere que el dueño de la villa tenía un profundo conocimiento de la cultura clásica.

**Próximo paso** – Los arqueólogos están preparando la publicación completa de sus hallazgos. El mosaico y la villa han sido protegidos como Monumento Programado. Los investigadores esperan que esto fomente más estudios sobre cómo la Gran Bretaña romana se conectaba con otras culturas antiguas e inspire interés público en la historia.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Un mosaico romano en Gran Bretaña revela una versión perdida griega de la guerra de Troya y muestra cómo la antigua Gran Bretaña estaba conectada con el mundo mediterráneo.
